data.title: .exe samples do not work when installed
data.body:
When a user builds Urho3D from source and installs the results, none of the samples work.  They all give an error dialog: "ERROR: Failed to add resource path 'Data', check the documentation on how to set the 'resource path prefix' "  The samples work in the build directory just fine, due to resolution of #994.  However the resource path is not valid for the final installation directory.

Several possibilities exist for solving the problem.  A claimed complication is that on Unix systems, the user may use DESTDIR to change the installation target.  The effective prefix becomes $(DESTDIR)/${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX} and it will only be known at installation time, after CMake has generated a native build system.  This makes it difficult but not impossible to use an absolute path, as the method for capturing DESTDIR would be build system or OS specific.  One for instance could capture it in a Bourne shell script.  This means the target development environment would have to use Bourne shell scripts, which may not always be a valid assumption.  A recent post on the CMake mailing list, asked how to handle DESTDIR in a generator agnostic manner, and claimed to have problems using the Ninja generator.  Nobody answered his question.

Easier approach: a relative path would work fine, as the end result is just installation to 1 directory somewhere.  The Urho3D installation tree structure is static and known at configuration time.

DESTDIR is a Unix-specific complication, it doesn't affect Windows.  Windows systems cannot use DESTDIR because they have a drive letter as part of an absolute path.  Concatenating absolute paths on Windows doesn't produce a valid path.  This is documented in the CMake docs and nobody uses DESTDIR on Windows.  Or if they do, they deserve what they get.

DESTDIR can also mess up various aspects of a CMake build even on a Unix system.  At least as of 2011 Alexander Neundorf, a principal CMake developer, claimed it would mess up RPATH.  http://cmake.3232098.n2.nabble.com/DESTDIR-behaviour-with-different-variable-name-td6261440.html   

```
DESTDIR has a different purpose.
Installing to DESTDIR does not necessarily lead to a working and correct
installation, mainly when paths are involved, like e.g. RPATH settings.
Assuming that CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX would be /opt/foo, your executable might
get /opt/foo/lib as RPATH, also when installed to $DESTDIR/opt/foo.
So they will not have a correct RPATH.
You really should set CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX.
```

Ergo, having the samples obtain a relative resource path, that is different for the build and installation trees, would be a sensible way to fix this.  One way to obtain such a path is to have a file such as "resources.ini" in the same directory as the samples.  It would contain the needed relative path and be read by the samples.  The contents of resources.ini would be changed at build and installation times.

data.title: ConsoleInput sample crashes with access violation
data.body:
Windows 7, 64-bit, VS 2015.  An UrhoSample and a ConsoleInput window attempt to pop up behind the Visual Studio workspace, but the sample crashes before the user can get any kind of focus.  Dialog is: 

```
Exception thrown at 0x000000013F0F73E9 in 26_ConsoleInput.exe: 0xC0000005: Access violation reading location 0x0000000204A2A000.

If there is a handler for this exception, the program may be safely continued.
```

Selecting Continue brings the ConsoleInput window to the foreground, and gives an Urho3D dialog about the problem.  (Incidentally, it would be nice if copy and paste worked with this text, so that I don't have to manually transcribe it.)

```
An unexpected error has occurred.  A minidump was generated to C:\Users\BVANEVRY\AppData\Roaming\urho3d\crashdumps\Urho3D_Fri_Oct_30_173329_2015.dmp
```

The .dmp when opened in VS 2015 pretty much has only the following informative bit in it:

```
The thread tried to read from or write to a virtual address for which it does not have the appropriate access.
```

This instance of VS was run with Administrator privileges so it's probably something more than that.  A pointer off in space?

I did not build with URHO3D_WIN32_CONSOLE.  The description did not seem relevant.

data.title: Urho2DPhysics sample could use a simulation reset button
data.body:
When this sample begins, 2D blocks fall onto a 2D shelf.  The following instructions are given: "Use WASD keys to move, use PageUp PageDown keys to zoom."  The 2D blocks fall very quickly and most are at rest within 3 seconds.  All are at rest within 6 seconds.  I'm not seeing a lot of point in using the movement and zoom keys, as whatever sim is to be looked at, is over.  The falling of the blocks is the primary thing of interest.  The only way to see them fall again, is to close and restart the sample.  So, one cannot set up the WASD and zoom keys to get the view one might want, one is stuck with the default view.  Or, one has to be exceedingly exceedingly fast to maneuver in the fractions of seconds before the simulation is underway.

If the simulation has a "reset / drop blocks" button, then the user can line up the view and zoom as they wish, and see what's going on.  Bonus points if the user had a way of slowing down the sim, but at least resetting it is the path of least resistance and advisable.

data.title: UIDrag sample: multi-button drag either doesn't work or isn't meaningful
data.body: The sample gives the following directions on the screen: "Drag on the buttons to move them around.  Multi-button drag also supported."  On Windows nothing like I'd imagine a "multi-button drag" behavior to be, actually seems to happen.  I would expect to be able to SHIFT-click or CTRL-click multiple buttons to select them as per Windows UI conventions, but this does not work.  I thought I might be able to click to drag a selection rectangle around multiple buttons, but this is not implemented.  Mouse hovering will select a button, and for some reason, hovering to a 2nd button will select the 2nd button as well.  But not a 3rd; the 2nd button will deselect and the 3rd will select.  Only 2 buttons at a time are ever selected.  Also when the mouse is clicked down, the selection goes back to only 1 button, so it is impossible to drag 2 buttons.  Either the sample is supposed to do some kind of multi-button selection on Windows and it's bugged, or it's not and the instructional text is not meaningful.

data.title: Short/small sound instances played concurrently are rendered sequentially, not simultaneously
CrowdNavigation sample requires middle mouse button
data.body:
The CrowdNavigation sample requires a middle mouse button to place or remove obstacles.  As the sample is demonstrating pathfinding, placing and removing obstacles is a critical feature for exercising non-trivial pathfinding cases.  Of 3 Windows laptops that I own, only 1 has a middle mouse button.  It's an unusual design I don't remember seeing anywhere else, and I've never actually used that button for anything ever.

Lack of a middle mouse button is probably typical of laptop users.  I just looked at Apple's MacBook Pro site, and their touchpad doesn't have explicit buttons at all.  Probably they have implicit regions of sensitivity, and it wouldn't shock me if those only emulate Left and Right buttons.  Culturally on Windows, a middle button just isn't typically part of the UI scheme.  A central "scroll wheel" is typical, and I do have side swiping emulation on all 3 of my laptop touchpads for that.  But this is not the same functionality as a middle button you can actually press.

Would suggest mapping that functionality to any reasonable keyboard key.

data.title: .exe samples do not have resource paths
data.body:
I am pretty sure that I have run .exe samples just fine in the past, either from within Visual Studio, or clicking on them in \bin when they're in the build directory.  Now none of them work, they all give the same message: "ERROR: Failed to add resource path 'Data', check the documentation on how to set the 'resource path prefix' "  I deleted the build directory and rebuilt clean, to be sure of the behavior.  This observed on both Windows 7 and Windows 10 machines.  I do get a big MKLINK error on both systems when first configuring CMake, but not subsequently. 

.bat samples run fine because they explicitly pass a Data directory option to the Urho3DPlayer.

Note that hardwiring a single path for the build directory is not desirable, as the samples will be installed and need to be runnable from their final installation directory.  Yet it is still desirable to have them be runnable from the build directory, so that people can trace the code with a debugger.  This furthermore implies that using a global environment variable to specify resource paths is not desirable.

Although the Docs do specify some ways to cause the samples to work, I submit that all of the methods given in the docs are wrong / this is a bug by design.  Samples should just work.  The build knows where the resources are, and where they should go.  This should be automated and not require user intervention nor reading the docs.

data.title: ParticleEmitter->GetEffect() incorrectly returns null
data.body: The effects are visible, but GetEffect() returns null. This is causing trouble in several LucKey projects after recently checking out Urho3D. In heXon for instance explosions get removed based on ParticleEffect::GetMaxTimeToLive().

data.title: Add function to control 2D physics update
Configuration header
data.body:
What do you think of using a header file to put all Urho3D configuration macros?
Also start using some custom types like `int8`, `int16`, `int32`, `real32`, `real64` etc..

This is my proposed file

``` c++
//
// Copyright (c) 2008-2015 the Urho3D project.
//
// Permission is hereby granted, free of charge, to any person obtaining a copy
// of this software and associated documentation files (the "Software"), to deal
// in the Software without restriction, including without limitation the rights
// to use, copy, modify, merge, publish, distribute, sublicense, and/or sell
// copies of the Software, and to permit persons to whom the Software is
// furnished to do so, subject to the following conditions:
//
// The above copyright notice and this permission notice shall be included in
// all copies or substantial portions of the Software.
//
// THE SOFTWARE IS PROVIDED "AS IS", WITHOUT WARRANTY OF ANY KIND, EXPRESS OR
// IMPLIED, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY,
// FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE AND NONINFRINGEMENT. IN NO EVENT SHALL THE
// AUTHORS OR COPYRIGHT HOLDERS BE LIABLE FOR ANY CLAIM, DAMAGES OR OTHER
// LIABILITY, WHETHER IN AN ACTION OF CONTRACT, TORT OR OTHERWISE, ARISING FROM,
// OUT OF OR IN CONNECTION WITH THE SOFTWARE OR THE USE OR OTHER DEALINGS IN
// THE SOFTWARE.
//

#pragma once

/// Engine version. (Semantic versioning #984)
#define URHO3D_VERSION_MAJOR 0
#define URHO3D_VERSION_MINOR 1
#define URHO3D_VERSION_PATCH 0
#define URHO3D_VERSION (URHO3D_VERSION_MAJOR * 10000 + URHO3D_VERSION_MINOR * 100 + URHO3D_VERSION_PATCH)

/// Detect compiler.
#if defined(__clang__)
#   define URHO3D_COMPILER_STR "Clang"
#   define URHO3D_COMPILER_CLANG 1
#elif defined(_MSC_VER)
#   define URHO3D_COMPILER_STR "Microsoft Visual C++"
#   define URHO3D_COMPILER_MSVC 1
#elif defined(__GNUC__)
#   define URHO3D_COMPILER_STR "GNU GCC"
#   define URHO3D_COMPILER_GCC 1
#else
#   error Unknown compiler.
#endif

/// Detect architecture.
#if defined(__x86_64__) || defined(_M_X64)
#   define URHO3D_ARCH_STR "AMD64"
#   define URHO3D_ARCH_AMD64 1
#   define URHO3D_ARCH_64BIT 1
#elif defined(__powerpc64__) || defined(__ppc64__)
#   define URHO3D_ARCH_STR "PowerPC 64-bit"
#   define URHO3D_ARCH_PPC64 1
#   define URHO3D_ARCH_64BIT 1
#elif defined(__aarch64__)
#   define URHO3D_ARCH_STR "ARM64"
#   define URHO3D_ARCH_ARM64 1
#   define URHO3D_ARCH_64BIT 1
#elif defined(__i386) || defined(_M_IX86)
#   define URHO3D_ARCH_STR "x86"
#   define URHO3D_ARCH_X86 1
#   define URHO3D_ARCH_32BIT 1
#elif defined(__powerpc__) || defined(_M_PPC) || defined(__ppc__)
#   define URHO3D_ARCH_STR "PowerPC"
#   define URHO3D_ARCH_PPC 1
#   define URHO3D_ARCH_32BIT 1
#elif defined(__arm__) || defined(_M_ARM)
#   define URHO3D_ARCH_STR "ARM"
#   define URHO3D_ARCH_ARM 1
#   define URHO3D_ARCH_32BIT 1
#else
#   error Unknown architecture.
#endif

/// Detect platform.
#if defined(__ANDROID__)
#   define URHO3D_PLATFORM_STR "Android"
#   define URHO3D_PLATFORM_ANDROID 1
#elif defined(__APPLE__) && defined(__MACH__)
#   define URHO3D_PLATFORM_APPLE 1
#   if defined(__ENVIRONMENT_IPHONE_OS_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED__) || defined(__IPHONE_OS_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED)
#       define URHO3D_PLATFORM_STR "iOS"
#       define URHO3D_PLATFORM_IOS 1
#   else
#       define URHO3D_PLATFORM_STR "Mac OS X"
#       define URHO3D_PLATFORM_MACOSX 1
#   endif
#elif defined(_WIN32) && !defined(_XBOX_VER)
#   include <sdkddkver.h>
#   if defined(WINAPI_FAMILY)
#       include <winapifamily.h>
#       if WINAPI_FAMILY == WINAPI_FAMILY_APP || WINAPI_FAMILY == WINAPI_FAMILY_PHONE_APP
#           define URHO3D_PLATFORM_STR "WinRT"
#           define URHO3D_PLATFORM_WINRT 1
#       else
#           define URHO3D_PLATFORM_STR "Win32"
#           define URHO3D_PLATFORM_WIN32 1
#       endif
#   else
#       define URHO3D_PLATFORM_STR "Win32"
#       define URHO3D_PLATFORM_WIN32 1
#   endif
#elif defined(__linux__)
#   define URHO3D_PLATFORM_STR "Linux"
#   define URHO3D_PLATFORM_LINUX 1
#else
#   error Unknown platform.
#endif

/// Detect endianness.
#if URHO3D_ARCH_AMD64 == 1 || URHO3D_ARCH_ARM64 == 1 || URHO3D_ARCH_X86 == 1 || URHO3D_ARCH_ARM == 1
#   define URHO3D_LITTLE_ENDIAN 1
#else
#   define URHO3D_BIG_ENDIAN 1
#endif

/// Data types.
typedef char                int8;
typedef short               int16;
typedef long                int32;
typedef long long           int64;
typedef unsigned char       uint8;
typedef unsigned short      uint16;
typedef unsigned long       uint32;
typedef unsigned long long  uint64;
typedef float               real32;
typedef double              real64;

/// Urho3D specific configuration.
#define URHO3D_SSE 1
#define URHO3D_FILEWATCHER 1
#define URHO3D_PROFILING 1
#define URHO3D_LOGGING 1
#define URHO3D_THREADING 1
#define URHO3D_D3D11 1
#define URHO3D_STATIC_DEFINE 1
#define URHO3D_URHO2D 1
/// TODO: Add all possible macros.
```

data.title: Fix Android MIPS build
data.body:
Hi,

While testing out the engine on various Android architectures (wanting to support all of them, as the engine is blazingly fast and smaller than it technically should even be), I came across an issue, or rather, the issue came across me - MIPS build doesn't work, random compilation error.

Seeing as that error is _something with graphics_, I've instantly gotten an image of the librarydrivereverythingOpenGL not supporting MIPS before my eyes, and that I won't be able to publish my app to such of an underrated architecture ~~no one even uses~~, thankfully it turned out (much) easier to fix than that - there is a collision between the mips constant used during compilation, and a random variable in the Texture code named the same way.

Having easily fixed it and verified that with the fix the Android MIPS build compiles (and runs, at least as far as the emulator goes) successfully, I request this to be merged.

As always, Thank You for Your work into making and supporting the engine! Keep it up!

data.title: Finding HashMap Node while it is being cleared returns incorrect result
data.body:
When shutting down the engine, Context destructor attempts to clear all the registered subsystems (calling `subystems_.Clear()`) which in turns trigger each subsystem to clean after itself in its destructor. The problem arises when one of the subsystem, Script, attempt to find an already destroyed subsystem (calling `GetSubsystem<ResourceCache>()`) in its destructor. In a nutshell, the HashMap::Find() call is done inside the HashMap::Clear(). In Debug build configuration, the Find() returns null. In non-Debug build configuration, it returns non-null value. In MinGW build, this non-null value crashes the app later (https://github.com/urho3d/Urho3D/blob/master/Source/Urho3D/AngelScript/Script.cpp#L163).

I am not sure how to fix this. Is it a generic HashMap class issue that needs to be fixed at this class? Or  it is a specific issue with Script class that can be dealt with by checking if the engine is exiting?

data.title: Unite Android hardware keyboard input with other platforms
data.body:
Hi,

While testing out the engine's capabilities on Android (which I've found overwhelming - that stuff works better than AAA engines!) I came across an issue - Android hardware keyboard input behaves weird.

And by weird, I mean truly weird.

Tilde (like many other keys, although this one is especially important to me amongst them) calls E_KEYUP and E_KEYDOWN only when no textboxes (such as the LineEdit) are focused, spacebar doesn't even get written in textboxes, enter key randomly defocuses textboxes where on other platforms it doesn't, backspace, while pressed, totally hangs the application where no other key would - and that's probably only a part of the madness.

After a long while of checking where such issue could even be located, and another long while of figuring out what could be wrong I rechecked my makeshift issue list, where the backspace issue led me to removing random conditionals which seemed unneeded, and so did seem event.isPrintingKey() - Bingo!

In short, not only isn't event.isPrintingKey() needed to block the keys that aren't supposed to print out anything (at least with the more common keys - never ran into such occurrence in my extensive tests), but it also blocks keys it shouldn't, causes random defocusing and may cause random hangups with (seemingly) even more random keys!

While it might still seem bizarre to remove a part of the code which ought to be a major check, in reality the "major check" does more harm than good (if it does any good at all), while it's lack seems to perfectly unite the Android behavior with the rest of platforms, therefore I request this to be pulled.

Huge thanks to anyone making and supporting the engine - You're doing a great job! Keep it up!

data.title: Remove defined_ from Sphere and Rect
data.body: Following the example of BoundingBox class, the defined_ member variable can be removed in favor of a Defined() member function, which detects the defined-ness from illegal values (max < min, negative radius)

data.title: SpriteSheet2D issue when scaling
data.body:
`node->Scale2D(...)` have different behaviour in `StaticSprite2D` using `Sprite2D` and `SpriteSheet2D`.

Using `Sprite2D`, scale function works correctly.
Using `SpriteSheet2D`, scale function does its job but add additional translation to the node.

Seems an issue with the center: 
While `Sprite2D` have the right center, `SpriteSheet2D` take the center to the entire texture not the sprite region.

data.title: Semantic versioning
data.body:
I think it would be suitable to follow the [semantic versioning 2.0.0](http://semver.org/) (MAJOR **.** MINOR **.** PATCH) since the current logic can be confusing (e.g.: 1.4 > 1.31) and libraries under many languages exist to parse this versioning pattern.

That's just a suggestion and I'm aware that it may break your current format.
If it's too much trouble under any circumstance (e.g.: @weitjong's hard work on Travis-CI), feel free to close this issue.

Thanks!

data.title: Add Z-up and handedness options to OBJ export
data.body:
Add checkbox options for "Z Axis Up" and "Right handed" to the OBJ exporter. Should cover basically all DCC tools' expectations.

Resolves the mirroring portion of issue #975

data.title: ResourceCache memory usage display in DebugHud
data.body:
Adds an additional table display that outlines:
- Resource type
- Number resources of that type loaded
- Average resource size
- Largest size of those resource (ie. size of the single biggest texture)
- Budget for that resource type
- Total memory usage for that resource type

Implemented in the samples as F3 key, to toggle on/off.

An image should explain it best:
http://i.imgur.com/pguB10g.png

data.title: OBJECT -> URHO3D_OBJECT
Bounding Box Issue
data.body:
Recently I updated to the newer Urho3D version (from GIT repo) but I see weird things happening in the 2D environment.

Rotating a 2D sprite cause a weird effect on the bounding box size.

This was before
![2drot3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1329119/10624813/956be9e2-779c-11e5-93b1-828f16185da3.jpg)

And this is after
![2drot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1329119/10624715/9038662c-779b-11e5-982d-ceaedbc7ac51.jpg)

At first sight looks like a wrong axis rotation.
I'm using Drawable::DrawDebugGeometry(...) to check the bounding box.

I don't remember exactly the old version but was something around Oct 10, 2015.
